BACKGROUND.Living Situation: The respondent is 50 years old, married, and has two stepchildren who are now adults and living independently. He resides in Georgia with his wife and a small dog. He moved from Ohio to Georgia about sixteen years ago and has recently stopped working due to his SMA-related health issues.
BACKGROUND.Free Time Activities: Since quitting his job in October 2024, the respondent spends his days walking his dog, reading, and engaging with his computer. He no longer participates in the corporate hustle and bustle and enjoys a more relaxed lifestyle. He also mentioned attending an abilities expo and being involved in Facebook support groups for SMA.
BACKGROUND.Journey with SMA: The respondent was diagnosed with SMA Type 3 around the age of 10 or 11 after experiencing unexplained falls. Initially, he avoided regular medical consultations due to denial and a lack of actionable advice from doctors. He re-engaged with healthcare providers in 2017-2018 upon learning about potential treatments through Facebook support groups.
BACKGROUND.Current Health Description: The respondent describes his health as generally good except for the impact of SMA. He experiences significant limitations in daily activities, requiring assistance from his wife and a caregiver for tasks like bathing and dressing. He notes a progressive decline in upper body strength over the past six to seven years.
BACKGROUND.HCPs for SMA Care: The respondent does not have a dedicated SMA care team but sees a neurologist who is knowledgeable about SMA. He sought out this neurologist several years ago when he became aware of potential treatments. However, he does not see her regularly and has not visited her office in about three years.
BACKGROUND.Reasons for Not Seeing HCPs: The respondent feels that neurologists do not provide him with tangible benefits, as they do not offer new insights or treatments beyond what he already knows. He finds the process of visiting a neurologist cumbersome and prefers the familiarity and convenience of his primary care physician.
BACKGROUND.Current SMA Management: The respondent manages his SMA with the help of his wife and a caregiver. He has participated in clinical trials and has taken medications like Evrysdi and Spinraza, but is currently not on any treatment. He is considering future treatment options but is hesitant due to past experiences and logistical challenges.
BACKGROUND.Number of HCPs: The respondent primarily interacts with his primary care physician and a neurologist, though he does not see the neurologist regularly. He also mentioned having a nurse practitioner, but she is no longer available, and he would need to establish a relationship with a new one.
BACKGROUND.HCP Involvement in Treatment Decisions: The respondent feels that he is the primary decision-maker in his treatment journey. He seeks out information and initiates discussions with healthcare providers when necessary, but does not rely on them for proactive guidance or treatment recommendations.
BACKGROUND.Primary SMA Doctor: The respondent's primary SMA doctor is a neurologist he sought out due to her expertise in SMA. However, he does not see her regularly and has not visited her office in about three years. He primarily consults her for prescriptions and treatment-related decisions.
BACKGROUND.Others Involved in Health Decisions: The respondent's wife is involved in his health decisions, providing daily assistance and support. He also mentioned an advocate for Evrysdi who has been helpful in navigating treatment options and insurance approvals.
BACKGROUND.Support System Involvement: The respondent's support system includes his wife, who assists with daily activities, and a caregiver who helps with bathing and household tasks. He also has an advocate for Evrysdi who provides support in navigating treatment options.
BACKGROUND.Comfort in Making Treatment Decisions: The respondent expresses a level of comfort in making treatment decisions, as he feels in charge of his healthcare. However, he acknowledges the challenges and logistical hurdles involved in accessing treatments and navigating the healthcare system.
BACKGROUND.Health Goals - Short-term: The respondent's short-term health goals include maintaining his current level of functionality and managing his SMA symptoms effectively. He is considering the possibility of restarting treatment with Evrysdi if it becomes more accessible.
BACKGROUND.Health Goals - Long-term: The respondent's long-term health goals focus on maintaining his quality of life and independence. He is open to exploring new treatments as they become available but is cautious about the potential challenges and costs involved.
BACKGROUND.Personal Aspirations: The respondent aspires to live a fulfilling life despite his SMA diagnosis. He values his independence and aims to continue engaging in activities he enjoys, such as reading and spending time with his family and dog.

CURRENT PERCEPTIONS & ATTITUDES.Treatments Awareness: The respondent is aware of treatments like Spinraza and Evrysdi, having learned about them through Facebook support groups. He is also aware of developmental treatments in the pipeline, though he has not followed them closely.
CURRENT PERCEPTIONS & ATTITUDES.Treatments Experience: The respondent has experience with both Evrysdi and Spinraza. He took Evrysdi on two separate occasions and participated in a clinical trial for a higher dose of Spinraza. His experiences with these treatments have been mixed, with initial improvements followed by declines.
CURRENT PERCEPTIONS & ATTITUDES.Discontinued Treatment Experience: The respondent discontinued Evrysdi after insurance denied coverage, despite experiencing initial benefits. He also chose to exit the Spinraza clinical trial due to a lack of response and dissatisfaction with the testing process.
CURRENT PERCEPTIONS & ATTITUDES.Discontinued Treatment Reasons: The respondent discontinued Evrysdi due to insurance denial after a year of treatment. He stopped participating in the Spinraza trial because he was a non-responder and was dissatisfied with the testing methods used in the trial.

Living Situation: Yeah. So I'm 50 years old. I'm married. We have two kids, but the kids are from a previous marriage, but I've been in their life. Corona was three, Jaden's eight months. They're now 24 and 22, out of the house.
We have a little dog, a little Morkey. I just quit working back in October 2024.
Free Time Activities: I walk the dog every day, sort of fiddle fart on the computer, might watch stuff, I read a lot. Not no longer the corporate hustle and bustle anymore.
We recently just got a caregiver just about a month ago that comes in and bathes me and then helps me with little things around the house.
Journey with SMA: I was around 10, 11 years old. I don't remember the exact date and time. There was a little bit of trying to figure out what was going on with me. I kept on falling down when running. Not all the time. So it was just my right leg that would give out.

To be honest, I was never seeing a neurologist on a regular basis. So when I got diagnosed at a young age, right, 11, 12 years old when my official diagnosis came in, I went into denial. I was still playing sports. I was still active. I did not want to hear what they were telling me what was going to happen, and so I sort of avoided doctors like the plague.
Current Health Description: Everything but SMA, I'm as healthy as any, but I mean, I have my regular physicals and all that. And I mean, I'm just, she was like, you are in great health, but you have muscular dystrophy.
Where it's affecting my life now is just my day-to-day abilities to do meaningful activities. My wife gets me in and out of bed. She dresses me. Up until recently, she was bathing me.
HCPs for SMA Care: No. I have a neurologist that she is in the world of SMA. So she knows, and I sought her out several years ago. I wasn't seeing anybody for a long time specifically.

Reasons for Not Seeing HCPs: Because what does the neurologist do for me when I see the neurologist? They don't do anything for me. I don't get any benefit from seeing a neurologist.
